conclusion: To determine if objects A and B have the same velocity at time \( t_1 \), we need to analyze the acceleration-time graph and understand how it relates to velocity.
The vertical axis represents acceleration (\( a \)) and the horizontal axis represents time (\( t \)).
The area under the acceleration-time graph gives the change in velocity over that time period.
Object A has a constant acceleration, represented by the horizontal line at \( a_A \).

premise: Object A has a constant acceleration, represented by the horizontal line at \( a_A \).
conclusion: The change in velocity (\( \Delta v_A \)) of object A from time 0 to \( t_1 \) is given by \( \Delta v_A = a_A \cdot t_1 \).
Object B has a linearly increasing acceleration, represented by the line starting from the origin and increasing to \( a_B \) at \( t_2 \).

premise: Object B has a linearly increasing acceleration, represented by the line starting from the origin and increasing to \( a_B \) at \( t_2 \).
conclusion: The change in velocity (\( \Delta v_B \)) of object B from time 0 to \( t_1 \) is given by \( \Delta v_B = \frac{1}{2} \cdot t_1 \cdot a_B \).
At \( t_1 \), object B's acceleration is half of \( a_B \) because the acceleration increases linearly. Letâ€™s denote this acceleration at \( t_1 \) as \( a_{B_1} = \frac{a_B}{2} \).

premise: Object A: \( \Delta v_A = a_A \cdot t_1 \); Object B: \( \Delta v_B = \frac{1}{2} \cdot t_1 \cdot a_{B_1} = \frac{1}{2} \cdot t_1 \cdot \frac{a_B}{2} = \frac{a_B}{4} \cdot t_1 \).
conclusion: At \( t_1 \), the velocity of object A is \( a_A \cdot t_1 \) and the velocity of object B is \( \frac{a_B}{4} \cdot t_1 \).

premise: The areas under the graph (representing changes in velocity) are not equal at \( t_1 \).
conclusion: At time \( t_1 \), the two objects do not have the same velocity.
